science models we need two categories of data the first is telematics data so this is
high volume high velocity IOT data which is ingested either directly off of sensors on assets themselves or via a
set of intermediary systems and then the second category is something we call contextual data this is additional
important or useful information about the assets we're monitoring themselves things like work order history might be

resource planning customer relationship and content management systems so at a

ran into is that all data but especially industrial data is very dirty so it
often arrives out of order it's highly volatile we often receive system-wide
snapshots with no deltas comes to us and many predetermined aggregations which
oftentimes don't line up with either the algorithms or the grains that our data science models require and then just in
general it often comes in duplicated partitions coated in all sorts of crazy formats
compressed and to make matters worse industrial data also has passed so a lot
of the systems that we integrate with or very old systems they were designed for other purposes as part of that they are
susceptible to a set of policy changes so we run into things very often where a
customer may have changed the meaning of a time stand from local to UTC time without recording that anywhere they may
have a certain field that they rely on in the context of that fields changed five or six times over the past 20 years
but they want to maintain that context for each of those changes and then
finally most of these integrations do have standards usually that they follow but unfortunately for us it's never the
same standard which kind of defeats the purpose of standards so that's the data
itself in terms of getting the data into our platform that's the second challenge that we have and the main challenge
